That's what I'm talking about! I need to find a great deal like this one of these days. This old stuff was built to last and that Chinese crap is designed to fail on purpose so you have to buy a new one, I believe the term is planned obsolescence. Anyway, great find and happy machining!

We only have EMD's and GE's running now at U.P. If I had to pick one I would say I like EMD's better because for some reason GE made it a pain in the ass to get to the #2 and #5 traction motor leads. Thank god I am skinny with long arms or I wouldn't be able to fit in there to disconnect them. I worked on both tonight and the EMD's seem better thought out and the components are easier to get to although the air start sucks when it runs out of air...no air start GE's. They each have their pros and cons but all smell like shit on the inside because of the port a potty in the cab.

Man that's quite the project but where else are you going to get a lathe for that price! I never really got into machine work, I'm too impatient, even though my dad has a lathe and mill. When you need to make a part for something they really come in handy. Awesome job saving this one from the literal scrap yard!

Been retired for 2 years now after doing 20 in the AF. I didn't get shot at or was never in any danger so with that said...I'm used to coming to work and thinking of the 100 things I have to do once I get there, not any more. I don't miss that part at all. I miss being around a group of people that wanted to get shit done so we could cut out early on Friday. Now I work for the railroad and it is the complete opposite mindset...don't do too much work because you will make everyone we look bad. It's their fault they look bad. I miss having a competent support system for solving issues. Now you have some fucktard who is related to someone higher up fucking everything up and nothing ever gets done. I swear I felt like I was surrounded by retards for the first year and a half but then realized these guys have given up on life and don't give a shit, it's really strange. Another thing, I'm used to moving every 4-5 years and I used to start getting in a rut after being at a place for 3 years. I find it very strange to think of being in the same place FOR THE REST OF MY LIFE. It's hard for me to blend into the community where I have settled down in because I don't have anything in common with anyone so it seems. I'm sure I will get used to it eventually or perhaps run off to Alaska...it's awesome there and Texas sucks. Ok I'm done.
There is a show on TV called drugs inc, I make my kids watch it whenever I see it on.
Walking off the field with my diploma...
Think of it this way...now the kids don't have to grow up with junkies for parents, they actually dodged a life bullet right here.
I've had more broken teeth than collar bones...teeth are bones also.

Yea I was very lucky to get it. I also have an old large pipe wrench that I got out of my grandfathers barn after he died, I've even had to use it a couple of times. Same here, my great-great grandfather and great grandfather were both farmers in southwest Michigan, my grandfather was a construction electrician and my dad was an electrician and I'm an electrician on locomotives. I was fortunate enough to have been around my grandfather quite a bit when I was a kid and he taught me the value of hard work and how to take care of things to make them last. These old saws are the epitome of hard work because that is all they had to cut firewood to keep their family warm during the winter. We take chainsaws and power tools for granted now days because that's all we know, I like using these old tools for what they were intended for and it reminds me of working with my grandfather. But you are right, these old tools were built to last unlike most of the plastic junk they have out there now. Companies have figured out the planned obsolescence part and design this crap to only last a few years until it breaks therefore keeping them in business. Almost all of the old farmers have sold out to corporate farms in our area of Michigan which is too bad but that's the way it is. Anyway I'm glad to see younger people (I'm 41) interested in this stuff as well. It was good talking to you and have fun with your saw project!
Here is the one I have: https://imgur.com/a/pfb0M Good luck with your saw, you never know someone might buy it for that much.

Have you heard of a website called crosscutsawyer.com? I think the forums are dead but they have a bunch of good archived info on saws. They have vintage catalogs and I was able to ID my saw from their 1953 catalog. The No 113 in the ebay ad has a curved back and the No 13 has a straight back (mine has a straight back). Mine is nowhere near the condition of the eBay saw, that one looks like new! But yea, mine doesn't have any rust but it's not shiny either and the handles are in great shape, it's still pretty sharp too. I plan on handing it down to my son when he gets older, he is 7 now so I'm going to have it for a while. I make sure to take it down off the wall and oil it down every once in a while to keep it looking good.

I also have a saw that was passed down to me. It's a Simonds No 13 crosscut two man saw that originally belonged to my great-great grandfather who was born in 1879 and died in 1928. I thought about cleaning it up and sharpening it but not sure if I want to ruin the patina because it was well taken care of and used quite a bit. You can see where they had to make the teeth longer by filing down the gullets and it is still sharp enough to cut with. I'll probably leave it alone for now and keep an eye out for a one man saw like you have to practice on. Let us know how it turns out if you do restore your one man saw and how many hours it took.
I've never actually restored a saw but was thinking about doing one so I did some research. I saw somewhere a guy used a lanskey stone and some kerosene to get it nice and shiny again.
This would be the way to do it.

I had the same "problem" for a while when I was around 16-18, I never really noticed it but my friends did. I just thought it was normal so didn't worry about it. Just keep hanging out with your friend and go do fun stuff.

A simple "yes" or "no". If you are being asked a direct question, do yourself a favor and do not ramble on. This will make you look like you are trying to hide something. I've had to question people before and most of the time after I asked the question and someone gave a short "yes" or "no" I would deliberately pause for a little bit to create the awkward silence. Most people can't resist the urge to say something and that is when they let more info slip.

Your point sounds like what Walmart did. They were able to out compete other grocery stores by having the most efficient supply chain which in turn allowed them to lower their prices. Let's say there was a cap on businesses. Walmart would probably only be in Arkansas but now the other, higher priced stores are still in business elsewhere taking in the money because they can raise their prices as high as they want since there is no competition from other stores. Bottom line, caps would stagnate competition and prices would soar. All bad for the consumer (me and you).

You also need to remember these guys were taken away from their country as a collective group and they were rationalizing to each other how they were going to act in front of the Englishmen. In other words they were getting their stories straight in order to get better treatment.

I do all my own work on my cars except wheel alignment so all that stuff. If I layed it all out on the floor in my garage you wouldn't be able to walk without stepping on anything but it is pretty small. I also like old vintage tools to hang in my garage. My favorite tool is a two man saw that my great-great grandfather owned and used to cut firewood with back in the day. My newest tool is a manifold gage set for residential air conditioning, I just used it today to put more refrigerant in my system. I only buy stuff as I need it. The way I see it, if I can buy the tools and do it myself to save money then that's what I'm going to do.

First, keep your hands where they can see them. Second, answer the question truthfully and treat them with respect. This greatly increases your chances of getting only a warning if you were speeding. Don't listen to these guys telling you to act like a smart ass and start asking the cop questions. This will only escalate the situation against you. The goal is to be nice and not give them any more reason to look further into what you are doing.
